;解放军8架战机越过台湾海峡中线并抵近台湾国防部表示，周六，台湾国防部称，这标志着紧张局势进一步加剧。

;

;过去三年来，解放军经常飞入台湾周边空域。自 8 月以来，北京定期派飞机飞越海峡默许的中间线，该线此前曾作为非正式屏障。

;

;3 月，台湾国防部长邱国正警告称，必须对台湾进行军事管制。今年，台湾对解放军“突然进入”其领土附近地区保持警惕。

;

;台湾将其毗连区定义为距离其海岸 24 海里（44.4 公里）的范围。其领海范围被界定为距离海岸 12 海里，但政府尚未报告解放军飞机曾如此接近。

;

;从周六上午 8 点左右开始，包括歼 10 和歼-10 在内的 19 架中国战机台北国防部发现了 16 架战斗机。

;

;声明中称，其中 8 架战斗机越过中线并“接近”24 海里标记。

;

;与此同时，五艘中国军舰进行了国防部所谓的“联合战备巡逻”。

;

;台湾派出自己的飞机和舰艇进行回应，并启动了陆基导弹系统。说，使用标准措辞来描述其军队如何应对解放军的入侵。

;

;北京声称民主治理的台湾是其自己的领土。台湾政府否认这些说法，并表示只有岛内人民才能决定他们的未来。

;一年来，斯托克顿·拉什一直试图说服拉斯维加斯的投资者杰伊·布鲁姆购买他公司潜水器上的几个座位，这样布鲁姆和他的儿子就可以体验参观泰坦尼克号深海残骸的千载难逢的刺激。

;

;布鲁姆很感兴趣，他说在周五的采访中。他现年 20 岁的儿子肖恩小时候就对这艘注定失败的英国客轮的故事着迷。

;

;但布鲁姆对泰坦潜水器了解得越多，他就越担心它的安全性。因此他说，他礼貌地拒绝了参加本赛季最后一次探险的最后一刻机会，声称日程安排有冲突。

;

;相反，布鲁姆说，船上的两个可用座位给了巴基斯坦出生的富豪沙赫扎达·达乌德和他的手下。儿子苏尔曼 - 本周，当泰坦尼克号在大西洋表面深处爆炸时，他与拉什和另外两人一起丧生。

;

;泰坦尼克号潜艇的非传统设计可能注定了它会带来灾难

;

;不到两周前，布鲁姆在一场摩托车事故中失去了一位好朋友、演员特里特·威廉姆斯，对于布鲁姆来说，这场悲剧提醒人们生活中真正重要的是什么。

;

;“每次我看到那位巴基斯坦商人和他 19 岁儿子的照片，我想这很容易就是我和我 20 岁儿子的照片 — — 如果没有上帝的恩典，”布鲁姆说道。

;<周四，在美国海岸警卫队宣布在海底找到了泰坦号残骸后，布鲁姆在 Facebook 上发布了今年早些时候他和拉什之间的一系列短信，拉什在短信中否认了这次旅行的说法。拉什在一条消息中写道：“虽然明显存在风险，但它比乘坐直升机飞行甚至水肺潜水要安全得多。”他声称，在一艘非军用潜艇上没有人受伤。 35 年。

;

;拥有私人直升机执照的布鲁姆不相信。他特别担心斯托克顿在泰坦号上使用的消费级部件——包括用于控制船只的视频游戏操纵杆——以及新颖的碳纤维船体，并且他对乘客无法打开的事实感到“震惊”即使在紧急情况下，也能从内部看到泰坦。

;

;“我对斯托克顿手术的情况了解得越多，我就越担心，”他说。

;

;吉列尔莫Söhnlein 于 2009 年与 Rush 共同创立了 OceanGate，他表示 Rush “敏锐地意识到”探索海洋深处的危险，并且“非常规避风险”。

;

;“警告没有得到重视”：James卡梅伦将次悲剧比作泰坦尼克号灾难

;

;但早在 2018 年，行业专家和拉什公司的一名前员工就已经提出了有关泰坦号设计的安全问题。

;

;布鲁姆说拉什的信心是不可动摇的。

;

;“这是他的梦想，”布鲁姆说。 “他是一个好人，我真的很喜欢他，而且我认为他的意图是好的。但他喝的是自己的酷爱饮料。”

;没有证据表明 Covid-19 病毒是在中国政府的武汉制造的美国情报负责人表示，研究实验室。

;

;在周五的一份解密报告中，国家情报总监办公室 (ODNI) 表示，他们没有任何信息支持最近关于该实验室三名科学家的说法是最早感染 Covid-19 的人之一，并且可能自己制造了该病毒。

;

;根据美国情报界各成员机构收集的情报，报告称，武汉实验室的一些科学家对类似于 Covid-19 的冠状病毒进行了基因工程。

;

;但美国“没有信息”表明他们对特定的 Covid-19 病毒（称为 Sars-CoV-2，或它说，关于任何“近亲病毒，或与大流行病源密切相关的骨干病毒”。

;

;这份向国会提交的报告包含未公布的机密附件，来自三名几个月前，议员们要求美国情报部门对 2019 年底爆发的大流行病的起源做出更全面的解释。

;

;一些议员声称该病毒是出于所谓的功能获得而产生的这份解密报告重申了 3 月份宣布的结论，称中国湖北省武汉市实验室的基因工程研究，北京掩盖了证据，表明这是一种人为疾病。 “几乎所有”其组成机构，包括国家安全局 (NSA)、中央情报局 (CIA) 和联邦调查局 (FBI)，都评估认为 Covid-19 不是基因工程造成的，而且大多数人也认为

;

;但 ODNI 3 月份的报告并没有排除当时正在武汉实验室检查 Covid-19 并可能因疏忽而泄露的可能性。

;

;国家情报总监办公室表示，对于这场大流行是否源于病毒的自然发生（可能是从蝙蝠等动物身上传播）还是实验室泄漏，情报界仍存在分歧。

;

;武汉实验室报告称，“为了公共卫生的需要”，该公司与中国人民解放军（PLA）一起进行了病原体研究和疫苗开发。

;

;但这项研究中使用的冠状病毒“关系太远，不会导致”。”。

;

;坚决否认Covid-19是解放军开发的生物武器的指控。

;

;“停止抹黑中国”：美国报告北京猛烈抨击“Covid 实验室泄密”

;

;国家情报总监办公室 (ODNI) 报告回应了有关武汉设施中研究冠状病毒的三名科学家在疫情爆发前夕感染了 Covid-19 的指控。< /p>;

;据称，美国情报机构发现，几名武汉研究人员确实在 2019 年秋季出现了“轻度”疾病。

;

;他们的一些症状与 Covid-19 一致；报告称，其他症状并不一致。

;

;报告还表示，美国情报部门不知道那些生病的人是否在工作中接触过活病毒。

;

;“[情报界]继续评估这些信息既不支持也不反驳大流行起源的任何假设，因为研究人员的症状可能是由多种疾病引起的。”

;2014年，一名失明的八岁印度尼西亚女孩告诉她的父亲：“爸爸，我可能看不到——但我希望全世界都能看到我。”

;

;快进七年，Putri Ariani 正在实现这个雄心壮志，因为她有弹钢琴和唱歌的天赋有力的民谣享誉全球。

;

;首先，她参加了印度尼西亚达人秀的试镜，并以碧昂斯的《Listen》的表演给评委留下了深刻的印象。她在 2014 年赢得了该节目的冠军。

;

;今年 6 月 7 日，现年 17 岁的普特里 (Putri) 在美国达人秀 (AGT) 的更大舞台上大放异彩，令评委和观众为之着迷。她高声唱出了她的作品《孤独》。

;

;英国评委西蒙·考威尔（Simon Cowell）以严厉打击未达标的想成为偶像的人而闻名，他在敲响金色压哨声前泪流满面，令所有人惊讶不已。 - 半决赛表演门票。

;

;回到国内，她代表国家出国的魅力赢得了数百万社交媒体粉丝和总统的称赞。

;

;普特里的前任SMM 日惹音乐艺术学校的老师说，他的前学生出生后不久就患上了一种称为视网膜病变的疾病，但他注定会成就伟大的事业。

;

;“我对她的表现并不感到惊讶。 [在AGT]表现很好。她是这里的模范学生，不是因为她的残疾，而是因为她的才华。”Okrifianto Syam Sworo 告诉《亚洲周刊》。

;

;印度尼西亚第一位全盲广播工作人员分享残疾人社区的观点

;

;也许最重要的是，她在美国的突破让年轻的视力障碍印尼人受到了罕见的关注，他们希望通过音乐留下自己的印记。

;

;“超级酷！”、“非常鼓舞人心！” ， “极好的！”和“太棒了！”当提到 Putri 的名字时，印度尼西亚泗水 YPAB 盲人高中学生的第一反应是。

;

;这是泗水为数不多的全盲学校之一，向所有具有以下资格的学生开放： ” /p>;

;“我不知道我是否有足够的信心去做 Putri 所做的事情，”学校合唱团的 14 岁学生 Nadia Lubna Dzakirah 说道。 “但是像我这样的人变得如此出名真是太棒了。”

;

;她的朋友 Nabila Alya Hamidah 表示，她对 Putri 的表演感到震惊，这次试镜现在在 YouTube 上的观看次数已达到约 3900 万次。

;

; p>;

;“当我听到她唱歌时，我激动不已，”她说。 “她太酷了。她的英语非常好，更不用说她唱歌和弹钢琴了。”

;

;Putri 已成为印度尼西亚的超级巨星，并​​受到许多政府官员的欢迎，其中包括总统佐科·维多多 (Joko Widodo)，总统佐科·维多多 (Joko Widodo) 向她颁发了本月早些时候，她在国家宫向观众赠送了一笔未公开的“零用钱”。

;

;但是那些认识她最久的人都记得普特里为了达到职业生涯的这一点而必须忍受的艰辛.

;

;在最近的社交媒体帖子中，印度尼西亚歌手 Melanie Subono 回忆起两人在日惹的一场演出中一起唱歌的事件。

;

;“[当她开始唱歌时]我无意中听到观众中有些人窃窃私语：“可怜的女孩看不见！”就连主持人也觉得在介绍 Putri 时有必要强调她的残疾。”她写道。

;

;Subono 承认，当她在 AGT 试镜中看到 Putri 被竞争对手平等对待时，她感到非常高兴，没有任何反应。提及她的残疾。

;

;“我们（印度尼西亚人）喜欢谈论其他人的不完美，就好像它们在人才方面很重要一样，”她写道。

;

;机器人化身由残疾人正在改变日本的工作习惯

;

;虽然 Putri 最近的成功为印度尼西亚的残疾人社区带来了希望和自豪感，但 YPAB 学生的一些家长在推动孩子前进所需的投入方面注入了现实主义的剂量。;

; p>;

;“在不否定 Putri 努力工作和坚持的同时，我们还应该记住，她的父母的收入水平使他们能够为她的培训投入大量资源，”援助家长 Rini Astuti 补充道，即使是没有残疾的人也会发现Putri 的成就难以效仿。

;

;Putri 的父亲 Ismawan Kurnianto 是日惹的一位烹饪企业家，现在担任她的经理，而她的母亲 Reni Alfianti 是她的个人造型师。

;

; “所有这些音乐和英语课程都不便宜，我负担不起，”里尼说，这反映了印度尼西亚大多数残疾人的生活现实。

;

;这位家庭主妇还表示，她希望印度尼西亚政府能够采取一些措施，为所有残疾学生提供优质的教育和培训。

;

;“该国可能有更多的 Putri Arianis，但大多数人缺乏手段他们的梦想成真。”

;

;印度尼西亚针对其疯狂富有的亚洲人征收 35% 的所得税

;

;根据政府官方统计数据，大约 400 万印度尼西亚人患有某种视力障碍。

;

;在 6 月 14 日与普特里会面后举行的新闻发布会上，维多多总统被问及他的政府是否会制定一项行动计划来帮助有才华的残疾人。

;

;“政府的外展活动不是无限的。我们不能照顾所有事情，”他回答道。

;

;回到 YPAB，当铃声响起表明合唱团练习即将开始时，14 名视障学生摸索着走进教室排练。< /p>;

;Putri 的成功让他们记忆犹新，全班同学向他们的女主角传达了一个简单的信息，当她八月份在 AGT 上登台时，她将再次代表他们和印度尼西亚。

;

;“祝你好运，姆巴克（爪哇语的妹妹）普特里！我们都为你加油！”学生们齐声喊道。

;香港消费者对为期一周的 29% 折扣反应冷淡为纪念 7 月 1 日的移交周年纪念日，通过政府应用程序购买的杂货和鱼类，称菜市场提供了更便宜、更新鲜的选择。

;

;虽然许多零售商相信他们的产品在本周内将保持竞争力，但批发商的集团表示折扣会损害生意。

;

;65岁的退休人员吴先生（只透露了自己的姓氏）说：“我喜欢在市场上购物，因为我可以感觉和触摸产品。< /p>;

;“我知道有折扣，但我不想访问网站或手机应用程序，因为这对我来说太复杂了，”当时正在铜锣湾宝灵顿道的菜市场购物的吴说。 .

;

;为纪念7月1日香港回归中国26周年，政府早些时候宣布居民可享受29%的折扣，“支付71%的价格”购买指定产品7月1日至7日在本地新鲜流动应用程序上的鱼类营销组织（FMO）和蔬菜营销组织（VMO）。

;

;59岁的家庭主妇马秀贤也表示无意学习

;

;“你必须用新鲜的鱼来煮汤，因为冷冻的鱼有腥味。我喜欢这样一个事实：我可以在做出决定之前比较不同摊位的价格，”两个孩子的祖母说道。

;

;香港 7 月 1 日的福利是什么？以下清单供您欣赏

;

;另一位菜市场购物者、73 岁退休人员黄健成表示，尽管有折扣，但他并不打算通过 Local Fresh 购买，尽管他是一名网上食品零售平台的老顾客。

;

;“折扣没什么吸引力。”我就是不喜欢他们提供的产品。”他说。

;

;张家荣，43 岁，是两个孩子的母亲，她说她在冠状病毒大流行期间尝试使用在线平台购买新鲜食品，但这样做她的选择有限。

;

;“当你在菜市场购买一种鱼时，你在一个摊位上有多种鱼可供选择。但如果您通过应用程序购买，您所能做的就是输入您想要的数量。我讨厌我在花钱时无法选择。”张说。

;

;7 月 1 日庆祝活动，1,000 家食品店提供折扣，吊起香港人的胃口

;

;The Local Fresh 应用程序由FMO与VMO共同开发，提供各种冷冻鱼类、有机海鲜和新鲜有机蔬菜，以及水培蔬菜苗，购物满400港元（51美元）可免费送货或到指定零售商自提

;

;邮报的调查显示，本地生鲜上出售的蔬菜价格比菜市场的价格要高。

;

;香港食谱中常见的甜山药芽，出售在应用程序上售价为每 500 克（17 盎司）36 港元，但在宝灵顿道菜市场的摊位上可以以每 500 克 12 港元的价格买到。

;

;其用于电话诈骗检测的 Whoscall 应用程序自 2012 年以来一直在韩国使用，韩国在线服务平台 Naver 于 2013 年成为该公司的投资者。

;“Whoscall 在韩国仍然很受欢迎公司发言人 Marco Tsai 表示：“这家台湾开发商在全球范围内拥有 1 亿次应用程序下载量，这一点也不例外。”这两个亚洲经济体在大约半个世纪前的同一时间迅速实现工业化，最近将彼此视为商业盟友而不是竞争对手。

;“两个经济体现在都在将自己重新定位到美国一边台北国立阳明交通大学工商管理学院教授胡金利表示：“从经济上看，韩国和台湾仍然处于领先地位。” ”

;

;“[台湾和韩国]有不同的优势IDC高级研究经理Galen Zeng表示，“只要信息安全保护和专利保护措施得当，合作的风险应该很小。” ”

;

;

;“韩国是一个重要的半导体制造商。联电发言人表示：“联华电子的市场，公司积极寻求加强与现有和潜在韩国客户的合作。”

;

;6 月 1 日，韩国和台湾的商业委员会吸引了双方约 60 名与会者总部位于台北的组织者中国国际经济合作协会的发言人表示，许多人参加了有关芯片合作的“积极”讨论。

;

;台湾对外贸易局的数据显示，台湾对韩国的出口额从 2020 年的 151 亿美元增至去年的 222 亿美元。其补充称，同期来自韩国的进口额也从 206 亿美元跃升至 343 亿美元。

;

;台湾税收协议能否帮助美国“削弱”中国的半导体发展？

;

;台北的独立科技评论员苏晓恩 (Sean Su) 表示，首尔政客通过更紧密地融入美国主导的世界供应链来回应对中国的担忧。

;

;苏说，韩国专注于存储芯片，而台湾则专注于存储芯片。更多地依赖处理器芯片，这意味着两者可以在不影响竞争优势的情况下合作。

;

;

;首尔将美国视为安全盟友，在经济上依赖中国市场, but relations between Beijing and Seoul are seen to be worsening under pro-Washington President Yoon Suk-yeol, especially over the Taiwan issue.

;

;In April, Beijing summoned a senior diplomat from South Korea expressing “strong dissatisfaction ” over the country's joint statement with the United States targeting China in the Indo-Pacific, which was made during Yoon's visit to the US. ;

;The US and China have been embroiled in their own trade and tech-sharing disputes since 2018, while economic competition between Beijing and Seoul has also heightened in recent years.

;

;Yoon's economic and foreign policies are moving towards the US and Japan, Hu added.

;

;Beijing regards Taiwan as a breakaway region of China that must be unified, by force if necessary. Most countries, including South Korea and the US, do not recognise the island as a sovereign state, but are opposed to any forcible change in the status quo.

;

;Countries that have diplomatic ties with Beijing, including the US, acknowledge the existence of the one-China principle stating that Taiwan is part of China, but they may not explicitly agree with it.

;

;“The Koreans are really important players, especially when it comes to Samsung,” said Keith Krach, a former US undersecretary of state for economic growth, energy and the environment, who visited Taiwan in 2020.

;

;But Krach said that South Korea has been “slow on uptake” to join the so-called Chip-4 alliance and that “if Korea keeps selling to China, it puts [the US] at a disadvantage”.

;

;The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy in Seoul did not answer a request for comment.

;

;South Korea's representative to Taiwan, Lee Eun-ho, told domestic media outlets in Taipei earlier this year he wants to support closer semiconductor ties between the two sides to “improve global supply chain resilience”, the Taipei Times reported in March.

;

;Taiwan's semiconductor output forecast to fall 5.6 per cent in 2023

;

; Sat, 24 Jun 2023 11:20:02 +0800 Taiwan-Arizona ties: the history behind TSMC’s decision to build US$12 billion chip plant in southwestern UShttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3225044/taiwan-arizona-ties-history-behind-tsmcs-decision-build-us12-billion-chip-plant-southwestern-us?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.24 10:00;
;;

;

;

;When the southwestern US city of Phoenix landed a deal in 2020 for a US$12 billion chip-making plant from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), it became the biggest payoff for the state of Arizona after seven years of courting business from the self-ruled island that China claims as its own.

;

;But the state has for decades been building close ties with Taiwan, even as it has been middle-of-the-pack among states in taking a hard line against mainland China, illustrating how long-term subnational diplomacy helps Taiwan expand its soft power abroad as Beijing tries to siphon off Taipei's remaining national allies.

;

;Groundwork for the TSMC deal was first laid when an Arizona delegation visited Taipei in 2013, with then-governor Jan Brewer and Arizona Commerce Authority President and CEO Sandra Watson. However, it was not until years after her successor Doug Ducey took office that plans for a plant in northeast Phoenix started to solidify, aided in large part by a US-China tech war and promises of federal government subsidies that would later be formalised in the Chips Act.

;

;“The previous administration and the current administration both played roles in this process, because it was a multi-year effort,” Chris Camacho, president and CEO of the Greater Phoenix Economic Council (GPEC), which was involved in discussions to bring TSMC to the city, told the Post in January. “That was a part of the discussion to get them to come to the United States, was ensuring that the Chips Act would move forward.”

;

;How rising industrial policy gave Arizona the economic heft to land TSMC deal

;

;Since TSMC's announcement, Phoenix has seen at least 14 other companies, five of them Taiwanese, announce related expansions to the metropolitan area, according to the GPEC. The chip giant's investment in Arizona is expected to eventually create 4,500 direct jobs, and 7,400 indirect jobs.

;

;While the Arizona expansion came amid intense geopolitical pressure to diversify operations, a “Taiwanese company will never invest money for political purposes”, according to Czeslaw Tubilewicz, co-author of the book The United States' Subnational Relations with Divided China.

;

;“The fact that [TSMC is] moving to the US speaks volumes, not so much about subnational relations, to be honest, but about a geo strategy and how important chip production is becoming to sovereignty and everything else,” said Tubilewicz, who lectures on international relations at the University of Adelaide in Australia.

;

;In recent years, the Chinese government has ramped up pressure on Taiwan's remaining diplomatic allies to get them to switch from ties with Taipei to Beijing. The Chinese government wooed away Honduras in March, and ties with Paraguay looked precarious during the country's presidential election this year. With only 12 countries left recognising the Republic of China (ROC), as Taiwan is officially known, subnational diplomacy has been an important driver of Taiwan's influence abroad.

;

;Businesses have other concerns, but rising tensions with China have made politics harder for multinational tech giants to ignore. TSMC has reportedly only opened a plant in the US begrudgingly. Analysts have noted that much higher costs in the US make it harder to justify chip manufacturing in the country from a purely economic perspective.

;

;Rivals have also been expanding their chip-making capacity in the US, with investments scattered across the country, from Texas to Idaho to New York. Arizona has long been home to a large semiconductor industry. There have been 10 major private investments in semiconductors and electronics in Arizona since January 2021, more than in any other state, according to data released by the White House.

;

;But Arizona's steadfast support for Taiwan over the years is a conspicuous differentiator when it comes to courting business from the island. Phoenix was the fifth US city to become a Taipei sister city in 1979, and Arizona was one of the first states to open a trade office there in 1987. That office was closed in 2007, but in March Arizona opened a new trade and investment office.

;

;“Arizona's partnership with Taiwan extends back decades and continues to have a global impact through the construction of TSMC's hi-tech semiconductor fabs in Phoenix,” Governor Katie Hobbs said in a statement at the time.

;

;Arizona's support of Taiwan goes back to the days of Barry Goldwater, an influential senator from the 1950s to 1980s and one-time presidential candidate. Goldwater even went as far as suing the administration of former president Jimmy Carter over the nullification of the treaty with the ROC to open relations with the People's Republic of China. The Supreme Court dismissed the suit, leaving the question over the constitutionality of Carter's move unanswered.

;

;This support did not go unrecognised. In 1978, the governor of Taiwan – a former provincial-level position separate from the office of president – acknowledged Goldwater and Dennis DeConcini, Arizona's other senator at the time, for their support for the ROC, leaving “no doubt that Taiwanese objectives were commercial and political”, Tubilewicz and co-author Natalie Omond wrote in their book on subnational relations.

;

;Since 2012, Arizona has passed 10 resolutions showing support for trade relations with Taiwan and allowing for international participation, according to results from LegiScan. Nearly every resolution introduced in Arizona related to Taiwan has passed, whereas the situation is the opposite in states considered more friendly to China, such as Iowa, where Xi Jinping spent some time in the 1980s.

;

;The state House and Senate in Iowa have introduced 31 resolutions since 2010 showing support for Taiwan regarding a variety of issues – excluding commemorations of specific dates and anniversaries – but none have passed, LegiScan shows. California has only passed two resolutions related to Taiwan in the past decade, both celebrating Taiwanese American Heritage Week.

;

;Oregon, another major market for semiconductor production, has introduced just one resolution on Taiwan in the past decade. The House introduced it last month, but it has not been put up for a vote. In 2013, the state House passed a resolution honouring a former consul general for “deepening the person-to-person exchanges between Oregon and the People's Republic of China”.

;

;“Even if Oregon wanted to compete [for investment from TSMC], there was no way that anybody in Taiwan would even for a second consider Oregon,” Tubilewicz said.

;

;While traditionally a Republican-leaning state – a position the political party of Donald Trump has seen eroded in recent elections – Arizona has not been as anti-China as it has been pro-Taiwan.

;

;In a 2019 report from Chinese think tank Minzhi International Research Institute and Tsinghua University's Centre of globalisation Studies, former governor Ducey was one of 17 US governors listed as “friendly to China”. But the only criteria for this assessment were public remarks that these officials had made about China, so the results should be “taken with a grain of salt”, as the Foundation for Defence of Democracies put it.

;

;While Ducey led a trade mission to the country in 2015, economic incentives to cooperate more with China are minimal. It is Arizona's third-largest trade partner after Canada and Mexico, at US$1.5 billion, but Chinese investment in the state is relatively tiny.

;

;Data compiled by the Maricopa Association of Governments showed that Japanese companies employed more than 14,000 people in the state between 2017 and 2021. China was not among the top 10 foreign employers. The largest Chinese employer in the state in 2017 was the cinema chain AMC, owned at the time by Dalian Wanda Group. Wanda sold most of its holdings during the so-called meme stock boom, turning what had looked like a poor investment into a US$675 million gain.

;

;AMC only employed 510 people in Arizona that year, while Japan's TK Holdings employed 1,000.

;

;Taiwan, too, has traditionally been a small economic player in Arizona. It employed 300 people there as of 2021, but that will change as TSMC expands operations. The value of Arizona imports from Taiwan nearly doubled last year over 2021, according to data from the US Census Bureau. That made it Arizona's fastest growing import market, while Arizona was Taiwan's second-fastest growing export market in the US, after the much smaller market of North Dakota.

;

;Meanwhile, from 2021 to 2022, the value of annual Arizona exports to Taiwan had grown from about 41 per cent of its exports to China to 51 per cent, jumping from US$620.2 million to US$764 million, US Census Bureau data shows.

;

;Still, the relatively little money at stake underscores how the Arizona-Taiwan relationship may be more value-based than anything else.

;

;“It demonstrates the importance of ideational issues,” Tubilewicz said. “Your moral values, your understanding what's good, what's bad, is shaping your behaviour.”

;

;In his final months in office, Ducey visited Taiwan last August at the height of US-China tensions over lawmakers' visits to the island, shortly after a visit from then-US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. ; Sat, 24 Jun 2023 10:20:01 +0800 As Malaysia cancels Jocelyn Chia, Asia’s comics open up on the risks of ‘crossing the line’https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/people/article/3225163/malaysia-cancels-jocelyn-chia-asias-comics-open-risks-crossing-line?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.24 09:30;
;;

;She has been cancelled, barraged with internet opprobrium and hit by a vague threat to get Interpol on her case, but US-born, Singapore-raised comic Jocelyn Chia is unrepentant over the gag that enraged Malaysia and kicked up a commotion over taste, decency and humour in Asia's increasingly patrolled online space.

;

;The notorious 89-second clip, from a bit delivered at a New York comedy club in April but that only went viral in Asia three weeks ago, carried a joke about MH370, the Malaysia Airlines flight carrying 239 people that went missing in 2014 while flying from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.

;

;It upset Malaysians, including the police chief who said he would ask Interpol to help track the comedian down, and drew a rebuke from senior ministers in neighbouring Singapore, keen to expunge any link between Chia and the city state.

;

;But on the other side of the world it has played differently, catapulting Chia to a hitherto unknown level of fame in the United States, where she now has a television special on the cards.

;

;“Life goes on, right?” Chia told This Week in Asia. “The advice [from friends who have been cancelled] is to keep putting out content and your fans will follow you, and your career will just keep building and growing.

;

;“This gave me some notoriety and a certain amount of fame but at the end of the day, my career will live or die based on the strength of my jokes,” she said.

;

;Chia's gag aimed a dart into the hypersensitivities of politics, nationalism and identity between Singapore and neighbouring Malaysia, nations bound by history and culture, but where gentle jousts over differences can segue into stereotypes and discrimination.

;

;Envoy says comedian 'not Singaporean' as Malaysia rages at MH370 joke

;

;Crossing lines through comedy is an increasingly treacherous business in Asia, several comedians told This Week in Asia, where race, identity and politics may play well inside a comedy club but can draw dangerous levels of outcry once on the internet.

;

;TikTok, where Chia's viral skit was posted, has since taken the video down for breaching community guidelines by containing “hate speech” or involving “hateful behaviour”.

;

;And even the defiant Chia said she was unexpectedly dipping into her training as a lawyer over fears she could face detained by authorities in Singapore were she to travel there.

;

;“I don't think it will happen, but I'll take a peek at the extradition laws when I have a moment,” she said.

;

;

;

;Indian stand-up comedian Radha Karia, 33, said given the climate of heightened sensitivity and the strong presence of mob vigilantism on social media, she had been extra careful about what she posts online, fearing that someday it might come back to haunt her.

;

;“The internet in India has become very cheap, a lot of people have access to it and when that happens, everybody has an opinion and everyone can get offended,” she said. “Indians are generally more sensitive when it comes to religion, culture, the language – anything.”

;

;When the authorities and online mobs stalk the internet, self-censorship is the outcome, she said.

;

;“From the start, [show producers] would tell you not to make jokes about religion, jokes about the government or jokes that might offend someone … which makes it more difficult for comics,” she said.

;

;Many comics have internalised the boundaries – on race, religion and incendiary political issues – instinctively knowing that the barometer of decency is calibrated differently in different places.

;

;“You don't have the right to cross the line on someone else's life,” said Singapore's best-known comic, known by the mononym Kumar. “You don't get too personal … Sometimes when I do it, I will always say sorry because I will feel like I did something wrong.”

;

;However, the imaginary line separating 'edgy' and 'offensive' from 'illegal' has become increasingly blurred – and crossing it can mean jail time.

;

;In India, stand-up comic Munawar Faruqui, who has been accused of cracking jokes that insulted Hinduism during a comedy show in Indore, was detained for 37 days by police in 2021.

;

;In Malaysia, operations at Crackhouse Comedy Club House were suspended after it was linked to a video of a woman discarding her headscarf and Malay dress, which authorities said was offensive to Islam.

;

;Malaysia's government spots a vote-winner: 'defending' Islam

;

;Meanwhile, Malaysia-born Nigel Ng – better known by his caricature “Uncle Roger”, a stereotypical middle-aged Southeast Asian man – who built an audience in the millions during the pandemic, found his Weibo and Bilibili accounts suspended after poking fun at the Chinese government, implying that Beijing uses devices produced by Chinese firms to spy on the population.

;

;Some comedians say the risks are now shaping content.

;

;Singaporean comedian Jacky Ng said his Malaysian friends in comedy were steering clear of sensitive discussions and directing their focus onto their work for now.

;

;One Malaysian comedian, who declined to be named fearing a backlash, said comics were trying to put up a “united front”, insisting spirits had remained “quite strong throughout it all”.

;

;Indian comic Ankur Tangade has received rape and death threats, on top of being stalked, after being part of a show which had a line-up of comedians from the Dalit community, who are the bottom of the Hindu caste structure.

;

;“I thought I'd try my best to not offend anyone since as a comedian, my job is to make people happy,” she said. “But I realised that people will hate on you even though they don't know what I talk about on stage. So I stopped trying to please everyone.”

;

;Experts speculate that in Southeast Asia, security and social cohesion may take precedence over freedom of expression – in stark contrast to that of liberal democracies such as the US.

;

;There are also political forces at play, said Ang Peng Hwa, a professor of communication studies at Singapore's Nanyang Technological University, suggesting outrage at Chia's joke – while offensive to many Malaysians – was juiced up by some factions looking for quick leverage.

;

;A small rally by the youth wing of right-wing Malay nationalist party Umno was held at the US embassy on June 9, a few days after Chia's gag did the rounds.

;

;“I view this as a highly political incident, politicised for whatever ends that these people may want to have,” Ang said. “We are not exactly following the West to the same extent of cancel culture. But people are looking and seeing how one might use it to cancel people they don't like.”

;

;Context remains the rule governing a good joke and the best laughs are often won in local languages including Bahasa Melayu, Tagalog or Mandarin, said Singaporean comic Jacky Ng.

;

;“We live in different parts of the world and we see the world so differently,” he said, seeing the outcry over Chia's skit as an occupational hazard of comedy in the internet age.

;

;“I think what happened has happened before, and will continue to keep happening: a comedian has a good set in the club, posted a clip of the performance online and people online take the clip out of context and react extraordinarily,” he said.

;

;“Personally, I will continue to do my own style of comedy and keep trying to improve as a comedian.”

;;2023.06.24 09:00;
;;

;A video of little girls at a kindergarten in China jokingly questioning boys about their ownership of flats, cars and money has provoked an online backlash against teachers who promote materialistic values.

;

;In the video, filmed at a kindergarten in Suining, a city in Sichuan province, southwestern China, a group of girls asked three questions of the boys: “Do you have a flat? Do you have a car? Do you have money?” according to a report on the news site White Deer Video.

;

;The boys answered that their fathers possessed all these things, saying: “My dad has all,” each time.

;

;The girls continued: “Then what do you have?” to which they replied: “I have my dad!”

;

;The video was shared online by an unidentified person who said it was taken by a teacher.

;

;The person said it was shared in a class chat group and expressed concern at the language used and the tone of the questions.

;

;“Is it acceptable for a kindergarten teacher to film and share such a video in the class group? I personally think that this kind of education is really misleading the children.

;

;“Is this kind of situation normal? Or is it just my personal perception?” the person said.

;

;Some online commenters said the video was created to commemorate Father's Day and was based on a trending content template.

;

;Many kindergartens in China have reportedly used the template to produce similar videos, some of which have been popular online.

;

;In response to the backlash, local authorities said they were talking to the kindergarten involved and pledged to conduct a thorough investigation.

;

;The hashtag “Controversy over kindergarten teacher filming children talking about houses, cars and money” has amassed more than 2 billion views.

;

;Many of the comments about it are critical of the kindergarten and the teacher.

;

;One person said: “If my child were studying here, I would transfer them to another school overnight.”

;

;Another added: “Are they teaching the girls to rely on wealthy men, and boys to just look up to their fathers?”

;

;A third person said: “This is truly nurturing children with distorted values from a young age.”

;

;Some criticised the kindergarten for filming the children and violating their privacy by sharing the video.

;

;“Why are so many teachers now acting as influencers? And they even involve the students in creating content. How can they fully dedicate themselves to education with such distractions?” said one person.

;

;Another agreed: “Teachers should not be allowed to film students and share the videos online!”
